issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) specifies acceptSupplyDelivery should take four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) — signature: acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int). However, both the template/example usage and the solution implementation use a three-parameter signature acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity) (ingredient name, price, quantity). This mismatch between the specification and the code is structural: students reading the UML/text may implement a 4-parameter method (or expect tests to use it) while the provided template/example and solution use a 3-parameter method, causing confusion and potential compilation/test failures.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the specification and code. Either (A) update the problem statement/UML/text to describe acceptSupplyDelivery as taking three parameters (ingredientName: String, price: int, quantity: int), which matches the template example calls and the solution implementation, or (B) change the SealSaloon.acceptSupplyDelivery implementation (and example calls in Main) to accept four parameters (supplierName: String, ingredientName: String, price: int, quantity: int) and adjust logic/tests accordingly. Recommendation: prefer fix (A) because the supplier name is unused in the current implementation; updating the problem text/UML to the three-parameter signature will reduce student confusion with minimal code changes.

issues.description: The problem statement specifies acceptSupplyDelivery with four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) — signature acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int) — but both the provided code examples and the reference solution use a three-parameter method that only takes (ingredientName, price, quantity). In the template's Main comments the call is shop.acceptSupplyDelivery("Bacon", 50, 100) and the solution implements acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity). This mismatch between the problem text/UML and the code (template/solution) creates confusion about the expected method signature and parameter meanings (i.e., whether a supplier-name parameter must be implemented and where the ingredient name is placed).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method signature consistent across all artifacts. Two options: (A) If supplier name is required by the exercise, update template Main and the solution to use acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) and adjust calls accordingly; or (B) if supplier name is not needed, update the problem statement/UML to specify acceptSupplyDelivery(String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) and clarify the parameter order. Option B matches the current code and is the smaller change.
